DataElement.preferredName: Primary Tumor Histologic Variation Classification Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Information related to the histologic variation classification category of a primary tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A tumor at the original site of origin._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._An alteration or difference from a norm or standard._A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

Concepts.definition: A tumor at the original site of origin.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.:An alteration or difference from a norm or standard.:A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
An alteration or difference from a norm or standard.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics related to the histologic variation of a primary tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.2.2 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002006. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A primary or metastatic malignant neoplasm affecting the bone or articular cartilage.: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

Concepts.definition: A primary or metastatic malignant neoplasm affecting the bone or articular cartilage.
Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

PermissibleValues.value: Small cell carcinoma of the bladder

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A highly aggressive carcinoma, histologically resembling small cell lung carcinoma.  In most cases it is associated with carcinoma in situ.

Concepts.definition: A small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma arising from the bladder.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare adenocarcinoma arising from metaplastic bladder epithelium.  It is frequently associated with long-standing local irritation.  The majority of cases originate from the trigone and the posterior wall of the bladder.

Concepts.definition: A rare adenocarcinoma arising from metaplastic bladder epithelium. It is frequently associated with long-standing local irritation. The majority of cases originate from the trigone and the posterior wall of the bladder. This group does not include clear cell and endometrioid adenocarcinomas.

PermissibleValues.value: Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder arising from metaplastic epithelium.  It represents less than 10% of bladder carcinomas.  The exception is the Middle East along the Nile Valley, where it represents the most common form of carcinoma because of the endemic nature of schistosomiasis.  Bladder squamous cell carcinoma is often associated with long-standing chronic inflammation of the bladder and usually has a poor prognosis.  The diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder should be reserved for those tumors that are predominantly keratin forming.

Concepts.definition: A squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder arising from metaplastic epithelium.  It represents less than 10% of bladder carcinomas.  The exception is the Middle East along the Nile Valley, where it represents the most common form of carcinoma because of the endemic nature of schistosomiasis.  Bladder squamous cell carcinoma is often associated with long-standing chronic inflammation of the bladder and usually has a poor prognosis.  The diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder should be reserved for those tumors that are predominantly keratin forming.

PermissibleValues.value: Plasmacytoid urothelial carcinoma of the bladder
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma, Plasmacytoid Variant

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma, Plasmacytoid Variant
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A variant of infiltrating bladder urothelial carcinoma. It is characterized by plasmacytoid-like features.

Concepts.definition: Invasive bladder urothelial carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant cells with plasmacytoid features.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that arises from the penis. Risk factors include phimosis and human papillomavirus infection. The majority of penile carcinomas are squamous cell carcinomas. The most frequent clinical presentation is an irregular mass in the glans of the penis. Treatment includes surgical management and radiation therapy.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that arises from the penis. Risk factors include phimosis and human papillomavirus infection. The majority of penile carcinomas are squamous cell carcinomas. The most frequent clinical presentation is an irregular mass in the glans of the penis. Treatment includes surgical management and radiation therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A high grade carcinoma of the kidney.  It is not a distinct clinicopathological entity and includes a diverse group of renal cell carcinomas which have been transformed from a lower to a higher grade.

Concepts.definition: A high grade carcinoma of the kidney.  It is not a distinct clinicopathological entity and includes a diverse group of renal cell carcinomas which have been transformed from a lower to a higher grade.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Diverse, mixed, consisting of an assortment of different kinds.: Of or related to the genital and urinary organs or their functions.: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.: An alteration or difference from a norm or standard.

Concepts.definition: Diverse, mixed, consisting of an assortment of different kinds.
Of or related to the genital and urinary organs or their functions.
Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
An alteration or difference from a norm or standard.

PermissibleValues.value: Sarcomatoid urothelial carcinoma of the bladder
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma Sarcomatoid Variant

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma Sarcomatoid Variant
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An invasive transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder that exhibits spindle cell sarcomatoid features.

Concepts.definition: An invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder that exhibits spindle cell sarcomatoid features.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A recently described type of renal carcinoma, affecting mostly young African-Americans.  It is located in the medulla of the kidney, and follows an aggressive clinical course.  Most reported cases have shown metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: A type of renal carcinoma affecting mostly young African-Americans.  It is located in the medulla of the kidney, and follows an aggressive clinical course.  Most reported cases have shown metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Carcinoma of the Collecting Ducts of Bellini

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Carcinoma of the Collecting Ducts of Bellini
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Also known as collecting duct carcinoma, this is a rare type of renal carcinoma. It arises from the collecting ducts of the renal medulla, and most authors suggest that this is an aggressive tumor.

Concepts.definition: Also known as collecting duct carcinoma, this is a rare type of renal carcinoma. It arises from the collecting ducts of the renal medulla, and most authors suggest that this is an aggressive tumor.

PermissibleValues.value: Sertoli cell tumor or Leydig cell tumor
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Sertoli Cell Tumor Or Leydig Cell Tumor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Sertoli Cell Tumor Or Leydig Cell Tumor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sex cord-stromal tumor of the testis or the ovary. It is characterized by the presence of Sertoli cells forming tubules. Leydig cells are rare or absent. It may be associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. In males, the presenting symptom is a slow growing testicular mass. Most cases follow a benign clinical course. In females it may present with estrogenic or androgenic manifestations. The vast majority of cases have a benign clinical course.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: A sex cord-stromal tumor occurring in the testis and rarely in the ovary. It is predominantly or completely composed of Leydig cells which may contain crystals of Reinke. In males it usually presents as a painless testicular enlargement and it may be associated with gynecomastia and decreased libido. The majority of the cases have a benign clinical course. Approximately 10% of the cases have a malignant clinical course and metastasize. In females it may be associated with androgenic manifestations and it follows a benign clinical course.

Concepts.definition: A sex cord-stromal tumor of the testis or the ovary. It is characterized by the presence of Sertoli cells forming tubules. Leydig cells are rare or absent. It may be associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. In males, the presenting symptom is a slow growing testicular mass. Most cases follow a benign clinical course. In females it may present with estrogenic or androgenic manifestations. The vast majority of cases have a benign clinical course.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

A sex cord-stromal tumor occurring in the testis and rarely in the ovary. It is predominantly or completely composed of Leydig cells which may contain crystals of Reinke. In males it usually presents as a painless testicular enlargement and it may be associated with gynecomastia and decreased libido. The majority of the cases have a benign clinical course. Approximately 10% of the cases have a malignant clinical course and metastasize. In females it may be associated with androgenic manifestations and it follows a benign clinical course.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neuroendocrine carcinoma of the prostate gland with unfavorable prognosis. It is composed of small cells containing neurosecretory granules.

Concepts.definition: A rare small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma that arises from the prostate gland.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of carcinoma that comprises a minority of renal cell carcinomas.  It is characterized by loss of chromosomes 1 and Y.  Based on the cytoplasmic characteristics of the neoplastic cells, this type of carcinoma is classified as classic (typical) or eosinophilic.  It has a much better prognosis than other renal cell carcinomas.

Concepts.definition: A type of carcinoma that comprises a minority of renal cell carcinomas.  It is characterized by loss of chromosomes 1 and Y.  Based on the cytoplasmic characteristics of the neoplastic cells, this type of carcinoma is classified as classic (typical), eosinophilic, or oncocytic.  It has a much better prognosis than other renal cell carcinomas.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Penis

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Penis
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A squamous cell carcinoma arising from the penis.  It occurs chiefly in the squamous epithelium of the glans, coronal sulcus, and foreskin.  Etiologic factors include phimosis, lichen sclerosus, smoking, ultraviolet irradiation, history of warts or condylomas, and lack of circumcision.  Human papilloma virus is present in a subset of penile squamous cell carcinomas.  Patients may present with an exophytic or flat ulcerative mass in the glans or a large primary tumor with inguinal nodal and skin metastases.  Morphologic variants include the basaloid carcinoma, warty (condylomatous) carcinoma, verrucous carcinoma, and sarcomatoid (spindle cell) carcinoma. (WHO, 2004)

Concepts.definition: A squamous cell carcinoma arising from the penis.  It occurs chiefly in the squamous epithelium of the glans, coronal sulcus, and foreskin.  Etiologic factors include phimosis, lichen sclerosus, smoking, ultraviolet irradiation, history of warts or condylomas, and lack of circumcision.  Human papilloma virus is present in a subset of penile squamous cell carcinomas.  Patients may present with an exophytic or flat ulcerative mass in the glans or a large primary tumor with inguinal nodal and skin metastases. (WHO, 2004)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Infiltrating carcinoma with lymphoepithelioma-like features that affects the bladder.

Concepts.definition: Invasive bladder urothelial carcinoma with lymphoepithelioma-like features.

PermissibleValues.value: Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma of the bladder

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A usually aggressive carcinoma composed of large malignant cells which display neuroendocrine characteristics. It is characterized by the presence of high mitotic activity and necrotic changes. The vast majority of cases are positive for neuron-specific enolase. Representative examples include lung, breast, cervical, and thymic neuroendocrine carcinomas.: The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

Concepts.definition: An aggressive, high-grade, and poorly differentiated carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation. It is composed of malignant large cells.
The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

PermissibleValues.value: Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the bladder

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare morphologic variant of bladder adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant glandular epithelial cells and clear cells distributed in a tubulo-cystic, papillary, or diffuse pattern.  There is a female predilection.  Clinical presentation includes hematuria and dysuria.

Concepts.definition: A bladder adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant glandular epithelial cells and clear cells distributed in a tubulo-cystic, papillary, or diffuse pattern. There is a female predilection. Clinical presentation includes hematuria and dysuria.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant epithelial cells with clear cytoplasm which contains neutral lipids. A representative example is the lipid-rich breast carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant epithelial cells with clear cytoplasm which contains neutral lipids. A representative example is the lipid-rich breast carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm composed of giant, pleomorphic cells.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm composed of giant, pleomorphic cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer that arises in cells that appear spindle-shaped when viewed under a microscope. These cancers can occur in various places in the body, including the skin, lungs, kidney, breast, gastrointestinal tract, bone, and muscle.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm characterized by the presence of spindle cells and anaplastic morphologic features.  Giant cells and a sarcomatous component may also be present.

PermissibleValues.value: Adenocarcinoma of the bladder or urachal
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Bladder Adenocarcinoma Or Bladder Urachal Adenocarcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Bladder Adenocarcinoma Or Bladder Urachal Adenocarcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare adenocarcinoma arising from metaplastic bladder epithelium.  It is frequently associated with long-standing local irritation.  The majority of cases originate from the trigone and the posterior wall of the bladder.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: A rare bladder adenocarcinoma that develops from the urachal remnant.

Concepts.definition: A rare adenocarcinoma arising from metaplastic bladder epithelium. It is frequently associated with long-standing local irritation. The majority of cases originate from the trigone and the posterior wall of the bladder. This group does not include clear cell and endometrioid adenocarcinomas.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
A rare bladder adenocarcinoma that develops from the urachal remnant.

PermissibleValues.value: Urothelial carcinoma with small cell carcinoma
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Urothelial Carcinoma With Small Cell Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Urothelial Carcinoma With Small Cell Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm derived from the transitional epithelium of the urinary tract (urinary bladder, ureter, urethra, or renal pelvis). It is frequently papillary.: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.: A neuroendocrine carcinoma composed of small malignant cells which are often said to resemble "oat cells" under the microscope.  Small cell carcinoma most often affects the lungs.  Clinically, this is often a rapidly growing cancer that spreads to distant sites early.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the urothelial lining of the urinary tract (bladder, renal pelvis, ureter, or urethra).
Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.
An aggressive, high-grade, and poorly differentiated carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation. It is composed of malignant small cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Concepts.definition: The structural organ comprised of specialized connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.
Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm derived from the transitional epithelium of the urinary tract (urinary bladder, ureter, urethra, or renal pelvis).  It is frequently papillary. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the urothelial lining of the urinary tract (bladder, renal pelvis, ureter, or urethra).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A radiosensitive malignant germ cell tumor found in the testis (especially undescended), and extragonadal sites (anterior mediastinum and pineal gland).  It is characterized by the presence of uniform cells with clear or dense cytoplasm which contains glycogen, and by a large nucleus which contains one or more nucleoli.  The neoplastic germ cells form aggregates separated by fibrous septa.  The fibrous septa contain chronic inflammatory cells, mainly lymphocytes.

Concepts.definition: A radiosensitive malignant germ cell tumor found in the testis (especially undescended), and extragonadal sites (anterior mediastinum and pineal gland).  It is characterized by the presence of uniform cells with clear or dense cytoplasm which contains glycogen, and by a large nucleus which contains one or more nucleoli.  The neoplastic germ cells form aggregates separated by fibrous septa.  The fibrous septa contain chronic inflammatory cells, mainly lymphocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer that develops in the lining of the renal tubules, which filter the blood and produce urine.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the renal parenchyma.  There is a strong correlation between cigarette smoking and the development of renal cell carcinoma.  The clinical presentation includes : hematuria, flank pain and a palpable lumbar mass.  A high percentage of renal cell carcinomas are diagnosed when an ultrasound is performed for other purposes.  Radical nephrectomy is the standard intervention procedure.  Renal cell carcinoma is generally considered to be resistant to radiation treatment and chemotherapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm characterized by a papillary growth pattern. A papillary carcinoma may be composed of glandular cells (papillary adenocarcinoma), squamous cells (papillary squamous cell carcinoma), or transitional cells (papillary transitional cell carcinoma). Bladder carcinoma is a representative example of papillary transitional cell carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm characterized by a papillary growth pattern. A papillary carcinoma may be composed of glandular cells (papillary adenocarcinoma), squamous cells (papillary squamous cell carcinoma), or transitional cells (papillary transitional cell carcinoma). Bladder carcinoma is a representative example of papillary transitional cell carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: A radiosensitive malignant germ cell tumor found in the testis (especially undescended), and extragonadal sites (anterior mediastinum and pineal gland).  It is characterized by the presence of uniform cells with clear or dense cytoplasm which contains glycogen, and by a large nucleus which contains one or more nucleoli.  The neoplastic germ cells form aggregates separated by fibrous septa.  The fibrous septa contain chronic inflammatory cells, mainly lymphocytes.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.

A radiosensitive malignant germ cell tumor found in the testis (especially undescended), and extragonadal sites (anterior mediastinum and pineal gland).  It is characterized by the presence of uniform cells with clear or dense cytoplasm which contains glycogen, and by a large nucleus which contains one or more nucleoli.  The neoplastic germ cells form aggregates separated by fibrous septa.  The fibrous septa contain chronic inflammatory cells, mainly lymphocytes.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma, Nested Variant

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma, Nested Variant
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A variant of infiltrating bladder urothelial carcinoma. It is characterized by a nested growth pattern.

Concepts.definition: Invasive bladder urothelial carcinoma characterized by a nested growth pattern.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma, Micropapillary Variant

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma, Micropapillary Variant
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An infiltrating bladder transitional cell carcinoma exhibiting micropapillary growth pattern.

Concepts.definition: An invasive bladder urothelial carcinoma exhibiting micropapillary growth pattern.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that arises from the urethra. Morphologically, the tumors are similar to those described in the bladder.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that arises from the urethra. Morphologically, the tumors are similar to those described in the bladder.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Carcinoma of the Collecting Ducts of Bellini

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Carcinoma of the Collecting Ducts of Bellini
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Also known as collecting duct carcinoma, this is a rare type of renal carcinoma. It arises from the collecting ducts of the renal medulla, and most authors suggest that this is an aggressive tumor.

Concepts.definition: Also known as collecting duct carcinoma, this is a rare type of renal carcinoma. It arises from the collecting ducts of the renal medulla, and most authors suggest that this is an aggressive tumor.

PermissibleValues.value: Small cell/neuroendocrine carcinoma of the bladder
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Bladder Small Cell Carcinoma Neuroendocrine Carcinoma Bladder

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Bladder Small Cell Carcinoma Neuroendocrine Carcinoma Bladder
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A highly aggressive carcinoma, histologically resembling small cell lung carcinoma.  In most cases it is associated with carcinoma in situ.: A malignant epithelial neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation.: The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

Concepts.definition: A small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma arising from the bladder.
A usually aggressive carcinoma composed of malignant cells exhibiting neuroendocrine differentiation.
The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.
